>From: Colin Green <cgreen@...>

>I kind of like the idea. As a substitute for the loss of history I was
>thinking of storing the generation number at which a connection was 
>created.

I got to thinking, and decided I liked the idea of maintaining history.  So 
I'm going to...literally.  I'll keep a list of genome changes that get 
carried along with the genome as a separate 'history' list.  Every change 
gets an entry in the list.  I'll even store entries for generation#/fitness 
pairs.  When the experiment finishes, you should be able to use that history 
to recreate the entire history of the genome from the initial configuration 
to the final configuration.  Mostly for human use, of course.  NEAT itself 
doesn't need it.

(capturing some thoughts...let me know if you see anything wrong with these 
ideas)

When a new genome is created by mutation, I will copy the old genome first.  
That will include its history.  It will then get a new ID.  Which will get 
an entry in the history list (maybe?).  Then, for each change that is made 
(connection added, node added, weight changed), an entry is made in the 
history list for the organism.

Likewise, for a crossover, I will start by copying the genome (and history) 
of the more fit parent.  I will create an entry that lists which genome it 
was crossed with.  And for every change that is made as part of the 
crossover, an entry is made.

As for elitism, they will get copied verbatim.  Even the ID will stay the 
same.  Then I will add an entry in the history indicating that it was copied 
as an elite organism.  Maybe?  Probably redundant...if you see Gen#/Fitness 
entries one after another, you know it was passed from generation to 
generation unchanged.

>Anyway this only relates to connections, maintaining consistent neuron
>IDs seems trickier. When a neuron is added it splits a connection, that
>connection has a source and target neuron, but several other splits
>could have occured in the past between the same two neurons. How do I
>know which neuron my new neuron is equivalent to?

I'm not sure I follow you...  In order for the unique ID of a connection to 
be the combination of the neuron ID's of the neurons it connects, it is 
assumed that the current neuron numbering scheme remain in place.

So perhaps you are thinking during the time you are creating the new neuron? 
  You want to reuse an innovation ID if you are splitting a connection that 
has been split before, right?  That will impose limits on the way the 
structure can be built.  But I'm not sure the implications of it...let's 
see:

Start with one input, A, connected to one output, Z
Split A-Z and get A-B-Z
Re-connect A-Z.  If you try to split that again, you can't.
If you split B-Z, you get B-C-Z, or A-B-C-Z total
Connect A-C and split it, and you get A-D-C-Z, so B and D are siblings.
Split D-Z, and you get D-E-Z, and C and E are siblings.

Drawing it out, it looks like it should work.  However, I suspect that there 
are structures you can't create that way.  For example, A-B-Z and A-C-Z 
where C and B are siblings.  The only way you could construct such a network 
with this approach is to support removing nodes and/or connections.

At first, that sounds like it increases the search space.  But having even 
more accurate identification of equivalent structures will actually narrow 
the search.  Perhaps you have struck on 'the best of both worlds.'

I like it...I'm going to do it.

My plan is to do XOR first, both a real XOR and a 'random fitness' version.  
So when that's done, I'll let everybody know what the results of doing it 
this way are, that way nobody else spends any time implementing a 
potentially dead-end avenue of research.

-- John
